{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3536057,"name":"","username":"GearFox","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gearfox/{size}/191322_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-22T02:46:13.500Z","cooked":"

Hey CD!

I’ve been tuning and running autos recently, and have gotten to the point where I’ve begun to turn up the max speed that Choreo is generating paths with. I have configured all the robot’s physical constants in my Choreo project, and have done straight-line tests where the the robot tracks the setpoint given by Pathplanner almost spotlessly.

However, when I begin to run more complex paths, the robot begins to lag behind the target pose quite drastically, leading to the robot speeding up near the end of the path and slamming into different field elements. I’ve attached Advantagekit logs and a video demonstrating this point.

I’ve so far attempted to use the Pathplanner DriveFeedforwards and move from a VelocityVoltage controller to a VelocityTorqueFOC controller, but without much improvement.

Advantagekit Log of a straight line test

Worse example of the test

Code

The drive motors may not have enough P to be able to keep up with the set velocity. You may want to try graphing the set vs actual velocity and see if that is an issue and tune the PID values from there.

I’m at the point on our drive motors where if I increase kP and further the motors begin to oscillate. I’ve also run Sysid and have a feedforward model for each motor.

a good tuning trick is to turn off all the feedback controllers in the whole system. you should be able to follow trajectories pretty well with feed forwards alone, and point out where the feed forwards may be incorrect or missing.

Is there a max speed and acceleration that you are setting? You may want to lower it to see if it allows the robot to follow it. Something such as 2 m/s for both should do.
